text.p: Italy's debt market slumped back lower after a short-lived rally following U.S. economic data faltered as negative sentiment again took the upper hand on the market, dealers said.

Italian BTPs focus was on the weakness of the dollar and the warning from the German Bundesbank that it was scrutinising a recent upturn in inflation and would not hesitate to tighten its monetary policy if warranted.
"The T-bond rally after the data soon fizzled out and BTPs were back where they started around one full point lower," said one LIFFE trader.

The U.S. data turned out better than expected with U.S. July retail sales up 0.6 percent compared with a forecast 0.7 percent, and July producer prices off 0.1 percent with a consensus forecast of up 0.1 percent.
Economists focused on the decline in the PPI which marked the seventh successive month to show a fall helping to allay fears of U.S. inflation and interest rate rises.
But T-bonds which rose around one full point on the data soon shrunk back and were now awaiting U.S. CPI data on Thursday to be convinced over the benign inflation outlook.

Italian PPI and WPI figures for June published earlier today showed producer prices up an expected 1.6 percent year on year and WPI better than forecast showing a 0.3 percent yearly fall against an expected 0.2 percent rise.
